Alex,
 
I think the three characterizations - biologic, optimization, and
e=
xperimentation - are very helpful in understanding different aspects of
neu=
roevolution and GA's.  Too many folks focus primarily on the
optimizational=
 aspects, to the exclusion of the others.
 
Scientific truths exist indepen=
dently of any human belief system. Hopefully,
we approach the them asymptot=
ically.
 
Ken Lloyd


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@ya=
hoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Alexandre Devert
Sent: Wednesday, January 27, 2=
010 3:38 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re : [neat] Horizontal evolut=
ion of evolution


  

Hi,
Quick answer : "yes". As parasitism-based and ne=
oteny-based evolution can be
roughly and subjectively put into an algo. As =
far as some selection scheme
is integrated, it will even "work", ie. provid=
e solutions better than the
initial population. But then, maybe I'm close-m=
inded, but I see three paths
:

- Biologic model =3D> So we try to be accur=
ate and we fit the model to *real*
data and test it over *real* data. Every=
 details count, even the weird
proteins mechanic in the cells nucleus. So f=
ar, not the main stream
evolutionary computation work.

- Optimization algo=
rithm =3D> So we don't give a damn about biology and we
leave it to biologi=
st. We design algorithms to solve problems, therefore the
design choice are=
 made according to that objective. Optimizing seems the
main focus on the e=
volutionary computation community.

- Open experimentation & tweaking =3D> =
Put here whatever you like, including
algorithm interpretation of whatever =
biologic phenomenon we hear about. No
goal out of... Watching what happens.=
 it's we discover unknown stuffs,
usually.

So indeed, whatever you like is=
 ok, as far you give yourself an objective.
If you want to optimize, horizo=
ntal evolution, well, gimme rational
explanations better than "nature does =
it". If you want to do models, yeah,
can be very very cool to compare to mo=
dels without horizontal evolution. If
it's for fun, yeah, can make a nice p=
ersonal project ^^

Alex

This is a=
n interesting article.

http://www.newscien tist.com/ article/mg205274 41.5=
00-horizonta
l-and-vertical- the-evolution- of-evolution. html?full=3D true=
&print=3D true

It talks essentially about the process that gave rise to th=
e evolutionary
algorithm and protein synthesis machinery.

I wonder if you =
could use something like it to tweak or build an
evolutionary algorithm?

W=
hat do you guys think?
